text: English grammar lesson 28 topic embedded
questions
part-2 have you seen part one if so then
you're ready to go on what I ordered
online for my children was the topic of
part 1 do you remember what I ordered
and put together it was a seesaw now
you've just heard me use examples of
embedded questions let's review what
they are
an embedded question is a type of noun
clause a clause is a group of words with
a subject and verb because embedded
questions behave like nouns we use them
like nouns which means they have
different roles in a sentence we can use
an embedded question as the subject we
can use an embedded question as the
object of a verb there are other uses
let me show you some of them
we can also use an embedded question as
an indirect object the object of a
preposition for example were you curious
about what Jennifer ordered for her
children here the embedded question
highlighted in purple is the object of
about a preposition now I'd like you to
try to use an embedded question as an
indirect object complete the statement
with embedded questions use the three
real questions listed shipping costs
depend on what shipping cost depend on
how heavy the package is where you want
to ship it and how fast you want it
delivered
let's talk about another use we can use
an embedded question as a compliment do
you know what a complement is a
compliment is a word phrase or clause
that explains or defines another unit in
the sentence a subject complement for
example explains or defines the subject
as in my main concern was whether or not
I could put it together when we use
subject complements the structure is
subject plus linking verb like a form of
B and then the complement in this case
an embedded question my main concern was
whether or not I could put it together
the embedded question explains the
subject an embedded question can also be
a complement in a noun phrase and then
it immediately follows the noun that it
explains or defines first example do you
have any idea who ordered this who
ordered this is the embedded question
it's a complement and it explains idea
second example there's no question
whether they liked it or not whether
they liked it or not is the embedded
question and it's a complement to the
word question it defines or explains it
and lastly we can use an embedded
question as an adjective complement so
it immediately follows an adjective to
explain it or define it or somehow limit
the quality for example it's surprising
how much shipping costs are the embedded
question helps to explain the quality
surprising I think some other common
adjectives that would be followed by an
embedded question are surprised amazing
amazed there are others alright now it's
your turn
I'd like you to complete the statement
in bold with an embedded question and
that embedded question will be a subject
complement use the real question listed
below
the statement this is what the kids
wanted now let's try using an embedded
question as a compliment and a noun
phrase again use this real question to
complete the statement with an embedded
question do you have any idea how long
it's going to take let's try one more
complement in a noun phrase use the real
question and complete the statement in
bold
it was a mystery how she managed to do
it all
and lastly an adjective compliment use
the real question to complete the
statement in bold
you need to be careful what you say
around your kids are you ready to go on
now
there's a special kind of embedded
question that makes use of infinitives
let me give you an example this package
it's actually not for me it's for my
husband it's a surprise
let me think where should I put it do
you know where to hide it hmm do you
know where to hide it use of the
infinitive to hide has the meaning of
should or could where should I hide it
where could i hide it do you know where
to hide it where's a good place so where
to hide is an embedded question and I
used it as the object of a verb did you
know where to hide it
let's practice more of these embedded
questions with infinitives
let's look at these two examples at
first I wasn't sure how to put all the
pieces together how could we rewrite the
embedded question to include a pronoun
as the subject of the clause we could
say at first I wasn't sure how I could
put all the pieces together how I could
put how to put mean the same thing both
are correct use of the infinitive is
probably more conversational look at the
second example I considered whether to
start or wait for my husband again we
could rewrite this and say I considered
whether I should start or wait for my
husband both versions are correct they
mean the same thing but use of the
infinitive is more conversational
now it's your turn to form an embedded
question using an infinitive can you
complete the statement use the real
question listed below
we can say do you know how to ride a
seesaw let's try an exercise
exercise to correct the mistakes and
then answer the questions
this exercise will review what you've
learned in parts 1 & 2 1 read the
statement and find the mistake or
mistakes then correct them the correct
statement I'd like to know if you shop
online this is not a real question we do
not need the question mark use a period
also we could use whether I'd like to
know whether you shop online or not 2
the correct statements how do you select
gifts for people does your choice depend
on how much things cost this is a real
question
but the embedded question needs a
statement word order how much things
cost three
the correct statement can you tell me
how quickly packages are delivered in
your country again we have a question
but the embedded question needs
statement word order for
the correct statement I'm not sure I
would purchase something from a seller
outside my own country would you again
it was a mistake with word order
five this one's a little tricky
the correct statement and more natural
sounding question is do you know where
to find used books and DVDs online if
you're going to use an infinitive to
form an embedded question the infinitive
follows the question word and then the
meaning of cooler's should is understood
do you know where to find six
the correct statement when it comes to
receiving gifts what matters most is not
what someone gives you but that the
person was thinking of you do you agree
or disagree if you haven't already go
back and answer the six correctly worded
questions I consulted these sources as I
put this lesson together I think you'll
find them helpful too
additional practice for this lesson is
available at English cafe comm follow
the direct link listed in the video
description well that's all for this
lesson thanks for watching and happy
studies
